question_sets.context:
Harry goes out after lunch. He goes in the tree house. But he can't find his football. He's sure Nick takes it away. He doesn't know where they are playing. He comes down and begins to play with his dog Bobby. His father comes out, with a bag in his hand.
"Where are you going, Daddy?" asks the boy.
"Mr Hill is ill," says his father. I'm going to see him."
Mr Hill has a nice garden. There are all kinds of flowers in it. And the boy likes to pick some there. So he asks his father to take him there. Half an hour later, their car stops at Mr Hill's gate and an old man opens the door for them.
Mr Hill is in bed. Harry says hello to him and then comes out. Rose, the little daughter of Mr Hill's, brings him to the garden and picks some flowers for him. The boy is happy and thanks the little girl.
"Do you feel like a cup of coffee, Harry?" asks Rose.
"Look at me carefully," says the boy. "Do I look like one?"

questions.explanation: The sentence means Harry goes out in the afternoon.
The sentence means Harry puts his football in the tree house.
The sentence means Nick knows the football is in the tree house, so he takes it away.
The sentence means Harry's father wants to see Mr. Hill.
The sentence means Harry goes to Mr. Hill's to get some flowers.
The sentence means Harry and his father go to Mr. Hill's by car.
The sentence means The two children go to the garden when their fathers are talking.
The sentence means Rose knows Harry likes flowers and picks some for him.
The sentence means Rose asks Harry if he wants to drink a cup of coffee.
The sentence means Harry tells Rose says he looks like a cup of coffee.
